headline: The Orderly Retreat That Isn't Retreating

sections.the_lead: While you slept, Bitcoin shed 2.1% in what Asian desks are calling a "controlled deleveraging" — the kind of phrase traders use when they want to sound calm about losing money. The move began around 22:00 EST as Korean retail unwound leveraged longs, cascading through Singapore and Hong Kong before European institutions opened to find a market already 1.8% lighter. By Frankfurt's morning, the selling had exhausted itself, leaving BTC oscillating in a tight $89,800-$90,600 range that European desks largely ignored. The setup entering US hours is instructive: we're down 3.1% on the week, yet spot ETF outflows remain muted, suggesting institutional holders aren't the ones reaching for the exit. The tension sits between retail leverage washing out and institutional conviction holding firm — a dynamic that typically resolves upward, though timing remains the expensive question. Solana's 4.7% decline leads the alt complex, with ETH/BTC compression continuing its slow grind toward cycle lows. Today hinges on whether US spot demand materializes at these levels, or whether the absence of a bid confirms that the $90,000 level was aspiration rather than support.
sections.the_lead_title: Asia Sold, Europe Shrugged, America Decides
sections.the_angle: Consensus this morning frames the overnight action as weakness. The smarter read: this is the market doing exactly what healthy markets do. Perp funding rates had crept positive for eleven consecutive days, building the kind of crowded positioning that makes corrections inevitable. What happened overnight wasn't distribution — it was hygiene. The institutions who accumulated between $65,000 and $75,000 aren't selling at $90,000; they're watching retail shake itself out and quietly noting which levels attract genuine demand.
sections.the_driver:
• Korean exchange data shows $340m in long liquidations between 22:00 and 02:00 EST, the largest single-session flush since early November — notable because it happened on a Sunday night when US institutional desks were dark, suggesting this was purely a leverage event rather than fundamental repositioning.

• BlackRock's IBIT saw $67m in Friday inflows despite the week's negative price action, extending its streak of positive flow days to fourteen — a divergence between spot ETF behavior and futures positioning that historically precedes price recovery.

• The SEC's Monday docket includes three crypto-related enforcement actions scheduled for announcement, creating headline risk that may explain some of the pre-positioning we saw overnight as compliance-sensitive capital reduced exposure ahead of potential volatility.

• CME Bitcoin futures open interest declined 8% over the weekend, the steepest drop since September, indicating institutional hedgers are reducing rather than adding to short positions — a quiet vote of confidence that contradicts the spot market's surface-level weakness.
sections.the_signal:
• Fear & Greed Index at 69 (Greed) — down from 78 last week, suggesting sentiment is cooling without capitulating, the kind of reset that extends rallies rather than ending them.

• BTC Dominance at 56.9% — holding near cycle highs despite the pullback, indicating capital isn't rotating to alts but rather exiting the space entirely, a pattern that typically reverses when BTC finds footing.

• Spot ETF cumulative flows at $31.2B — still accelerating on a 30-day basis despite the week's price action, the kind of structural demand that eventually overwhelms short-term positioning games.
sections.the_takeaway: Markets don't reward you for buying when everyone else is buying — they reward you for noticing when the people selling are different from the people who bought.

image_keywords: Manhattan skyline, soft morning light, glass towers, bright
